People revere and celebrate him not just for starting the EV and space flight revolution but for maintaining their perilous survival as they extended over the chasm of death. I really liked this one, Tim.
But I felt something important was missing.
When you had Elon talking, I was wondering why you did not ask more on how the tower is supposed to catch the booster or the ship.
When a falcon first stage lands, some titanium shape in the landing legs absorbs the remaining kinetic energy of the ship by deforming, despite the falcon's suicide burn.
Obviously, the ship and even more the booster are so heavy, that any remaining speed has so much energy it cannot be absorbed by the tower nor by the vehicle itself without causing damage.
Something has to absorb that energy, but I can't see what part of the tower would be able to do that.
I really expected some shock breaker, energy absorber component somewhere.
Also, I would expect the tower/chopsticks to communicate with the booster/starship during the last seconds, to indicate exactly how much distance it still has, before its downward speed should be 0, just to minimize the remaining kinetic energy.
Next time you see Elon, please ask. 🙂

The Space Vacuum.

The reason for this is to share with you an idea of ​​a system to clean the atmosphere, the ozone layer of pollution generated by man. With the idea that I propose, it will be possible to clean the atmosphere to a large extent, and thus avoid global warming and all its consequences.

My project is called "The Space Vacuum"

it consists of a platform placed in orbit, similar to a space station, which has a gigantic tube so to speak that connects outer space and the atmosphere.
The space vacuum takes advantage of the "suction force of the space vacuum", Things are "pushed" by pressure, more specifically by the difference in pressure of a gaseous medium between two adjacent areas. Suppose a spaceship bursts the hatch and everything goes flying. In reality, the vacuum did not pull anything, but everything loose was pushed from the area of ​​higher pressure to the area of ​​lower pressure.

The same effect is achieved if we connect the atmosphere to outer space by means of a gigantic tube, and thus suck out the pollution, all the greenhouse gases along with the pollution would be expelled out of the earth into space, where they do not harm the Earth. ozone layer. By connecting outer space with the earth's atmosphere a bridge would be created, this bridge is the gigantic tube that allows the expulsion of greenhouse gases.

The space vacuum would have a system of chambers and valves that open and close to control what is ejected into space. You understand me? The tube has a mechanism that opens and closes as needed, thus controlling the suction, thus preventing all the oxygen in the atmosphere from escaping.

Harnessing the space vacuum cleaner.

- All the garbage on the planet could be expelled into space.

- All radioactive material could be expelled from nuclear power plants.

-In the event of a third world war, the atmosphere can be cleaned of radioactive contamination, gases, dust and thus avoid a nuclear winter.

- Capsules can be created to send humans to space, tools and equipment, something like an elevator to space, thus being totally carbon neutral, zero pollutant.

- Could be used by Elon Musk to capture Co2 and turn it into fuel

The space vacuum cleaner could save man from extinction and life in general on planet Earth.

[Suggestions / Propellant Production Plant] Great job as always. I have so many questions about every piece of ground equipment (Stage 0) at Starbase, including about SpaceX's propellant production plant. (but I doubt this information is available).
Requirements: How much propellant do they use per month (or do they anticipate using per month)? What is the operation like that currently delivers that?
Progress: Have they been able to produce any propellants on site at their own propellant production plant that they can use? What are the engineering details of that plant? the challenges? the missteps? the future plans?
Forecasts: What are the forecasts of how much of the required propellant can be supplied by the plant? How similar is the plant to the one they anticipate building on Mars? Do they anticipate building such a plant at Kennedy Space Center as well? At other future launch locations? How does the propellant production process relate with carbon capture efforts?
... and so much more ...

A question I'd like answered if at all possible: Current Falcon 9 booster landings are relatively accurate, but orders of magnitude less accurate than what is aimed for with the Starship boosters. Is SpaceX starting to tweak the software and hardware control on the Falcon 9 to dial in landing accuracy at all? I understand that the Falcon 9 cannot hover, hence the "suicide burn" nature of the landings, which will obviously not be the case with the Starship booster. But with the high launch-cadence of the Falcon 9, surely it makes sense to learn and grow with an existing launch-system, rather than failing iteratively with larger and more expensive experimental boosters and ships?

Starting in the 90s the practically of reusability became feasible but NASA's budgets were still tied up with legacy rocket building techniques.

Now that SpaceX demonstrated it can be done, companies that don't produce reusable rockets can't compete on launch costs so SpaceX is inch-by-inch gobbled up launch industry. It's competitors at the moment are really just backups in case SpaceX has some major incident. NASA is unfortunately spending ridiculous amounts of money for Ares rocket when it would have been a lot cheaper just to run with Starship.

Landing struts will be needed eventually, so why remove them? I suppose starship will eventually have to land on unprepared areas on Moon and Mars without "chopsticks" that will catch it...right?
Maybe installing fixed (unretractable) struts, that are simple, sturdy and easily replaceable. 4 struts with functional surface(s) on bottom that can be used as heat shield and aerodynamic control surface while reentering. For example, refuel before reentering or bring more fuel up, so that main engines may provide trust for max deceleration in vacuum and thin air. Exhaust gases might protect engines from incoming hot air, while landing struts might be used as aerodynamic attitude controls (like canards), as airbrakes, maybe even create shockwave that deflects incoming air away from the body (if that's possible), and be used for landing. After which is replaced. On Moon and Mars with little thermal stress for reentry, landing struts might be reusable.

Good economy is the one that grows naturally with little pressure. Usually due to untapped resources (like in USSR), untapped technology (like industrial, computer, information boom), untapped population (like in China). Bad economy is the one that grows unnaturally, due to high pressure for keeping the growth (speculative trends, hyper consumerism, inventing values out of thin air, etc.).

Conquering solar system is not gonna happen overnight. I see at least three huge steps that need to become cheap and unchallenging undertakings...1. Earth orbit, 2. Moon, 3.Mars.
What Musk is proposing (direct to Mars) is kind of like pacific tribes in rafts, settling different islands, and staying there. With not much progress, but majority of time spending on survival.
Its not bad, but its not good either. There needs to be connecting infrastructure in order to keep progress and avoid spending all energy on survival.

This "Catching approach" is highly likely to fail. Statistically too many components are at risk. The booster, or the arms, or the tower will get damaged or destroyed. Better to have the booster separate on return and land independently. It will be lighter enabling landing, and it's established technology, also less components at risk, (ie no tower, or arms, or arms that can damage the booster)...

One thing which really makes me curious is why no flame trench for the launch tower. So many engines running (more than the Soviet N-1 even!) and so much thrust - more than any other rocket in history - and all that fire and noise hits dead-on a flat concrete pad? What's that pad going to look like after just a few launches? Surely the concrete has to abrade at quite a rate.

Also, with so much methane boiling off and venting every time this thing is tanked up and drained, what mitigation efforts are SpaceX taking to compensate for that? Maybe doesn't matter much right now, but if massive fleets of Starships are going to be launching all the time at some vague point in the future for our still-to-come off-world colony efforts, that'd be something we'd have to think about methinks.

What people never seem to grasp - especially, and bafflingly, a great many politicians and even economists - is that economic growth is actually driven by technology, because technology drives two things and two things only: greater productivity (more stuff out for less energy/labor in) and efficiency (less energy/labor required to achieve the same thing). Combined, those titanic forces of human progress, which actually exist in a compound feedback loop, are measured (inaccurately) in terms of what is called "economic growth".
Creating a 100% reusable launch system will represent one of the greatest boosts to productivity and efficiency of all time.

We are all one people, on one earth, and if we can complete our evolution to at least the point of cooperation, acceptance of others (no racism etc), worked toward common good the outcome is almost unfathomable. I led a life outside the norm, a ski bum/instructor, chef at night, and roofer in summer then picking up other trades until becoming general contractor building gigantic custom homes in Santa Barbara CA, Breckenridge CO, and Paradise Valley/Scottdale etc in the valley of the sun in AZ. It was in Santa Barbara though when my awesome life of skiing, mt biking, climbing, fishing, hiking, mountaineering etc reached a level unimaginable really, that made all my life of fun and adventure up until that point at 35yrs feel literally like hell in comparison. I was pondering why I wasn't even happier, having such an amazing existence up to that point I knew inherently something was missing, like there was just something i was overlooking holding me back. So I took a vacation, my first in a decade for I loved work and we made that fun as well... I did learn early most everything can be fun IF YOU ALLOW IT TO BE we make work not fun by simply not enjoying doing it... when it is actually all our choice... we have that power inherently. So I bought this little book I had thumbed through years before that rang of truth, and a 2nd book the author had just released. The author was promoting the book on Oprah Winfrey a show I never watched but happen to see and advertisement about this author and his new book the same day I was questioning my level of happiness... or perhaps my tendency to feel boredom or mundane blah. The first day of vacation i read the book, it isnt a long difficult book but I noticed many times I had to stop reading and go back a page or 2 because it turns out my mind went on autopilot, and kept reading while i was thinking of other things. Like when your driving and dont recall sections of the drive, your mind wandering about tomorrow's work or yesterdays mistakes, maybe resentments, or past great times even... yet we drive just fine... most of us, some of us lmao, the whole time. Anyhow so i really liked the book it just was oozing simple logical truths yet my ability to really read and only do that single thing was an effort. So on day 2 I restarted reading the book, focusing on reading only and not letting my mind wander, about halfway through the 2nd read something clicked within me, well it was more like something clicked into the correct perspective/function, which in turn clicked something else into its proper "place", clicking another and another and another through this seeming tidal wave of perfect prestine allignment. Bliss and the wisdom of all the universe poured into my being like a huge waterfall of amazing bliss, and from within me seemed to shine the most brilliant light that seemed to illuminate the world with depth, color, textures and resonating life in all things including thing we normally see as stationary, such as trees, rocks, earth etc, all was alive, connected, interacting, relating with colors brighter and more vivid than i could have ever conceived possible, the world looked 4 dimenional or 5,6 etc dimensional instead of our 3 dimensional typical view. I understood EVERYTHING in how the the universe truly worked, its prestine, absurdly simple perfection, and how we tend to "miss this fundamental universal function" that makes EVERTHING makes perfect sense, no more confusions of why this or that, why rich or poor, sickness or health, addiction, homelessness etc.... all replaced with absolute, simple, prestine, honest truth that is incredibly challenging to put into words. Thus many teaching call it wisdom beyond words.... our language evolves naturally as our species does so someday it may be easy to put this wisdom into words, in fact its quite possible we may evolve telepathy of sorts and not need words at all, or even technological devices such as nueralink that allow us to "mind meld" like spock in star trek. I was not as fortunate as some to shift to enlightenment and simply remain there, not long after enlightenment a friend came by and I tried to explain the astounding experience/change that had just occured to me, and just a few words into my explanation attempt I shifted back to my "previous/normal" concious awareness level... which up until that day I had felt was pretty awesome comparitively, I thought i was living the dream yet relative to how the state of enlightenment felt, my normal reality literally felt like hell. Not because it was bad, only enlightenment is incomparably "better", it is absolute, prestine, perfect, simple perfection that puts you in a "base state" of peaceful, harmonious contentment, up to enthusiasm, inspiration, joy and even absolute bliss.... not emotions but states of being. I wont get into the difference here other than to say emotions are not meant for us to feel them and become angry, sad, or even positive seeming ones such as what we tend to call happiness of say getting a car, some vanity, or other ego serving things.
After shifting from bliss back to the hellish feeling of normal consciousness i was horrified.... i had "lost it all" in an instant.... and I had no idea if that was it, or if I could return somehow... I knew it was supposed to be our natural state, but i wasnt yet aware of what keeps us from experiencing that state yet.... some teaching call tbose things we do or dont do which keeps us from experiencing what Christ called "heaven right here in the midst of you". I though ok, reading the book got me there so maybe it can bring me back, and sure enough it did.... i didnt realize exactly how at the time but in the next decade of me studying many wisdon teachings/spirtuality teachings/religion core teachings without the dogma crap i learned much and gained much "personal power" as one teaching refers to it, so that I can return to zen, stay in zen, etc more or less whenever i wanted. So one othe the thousand heads of the beast it turns out is being fully present, something most of us are not typically great at. Our minds wander all day long, even when doing thing which you would think would require all/most of our intention like driving but nope... we can go on autopilot with most anytbing we have done quite often.... you could compare that to the honeymoon period, and not just with people but any task or doing, it could be learning a new fun thing like biking. Initially intense focus and intense happiness when getting it right or frustration/anger etc when getting it wrong. Notice emotions all have opposites, and they are their truly to guide us back to being centered, balanced, harmonious and peaceful so that we can rise up in states of being... instead of being emotional wrecks throwing tantrums or over exubrance etc. Humanity maybe the first being to consciously evolve as a species, it is what is occuring now, if we can save ourselves from ourselves.... and Elon is a huge part of this equation. Anyone who made it this far, I sure hope something clicked, nothi g would make me fill with joy more than assisting another human into experience enlightenment even for a moment. I'm not sure if this has been addresses elsewhere- What's the reason that building launch towers is preferred to digging underground silos? I'm sure cost is a big issue, but it would seem that having the boosters held underground and being able ingress/egress the capsule or load payloads at ground level would be convenient.  If they have the accuracy of the landing worked out to a small enough margin of error that they can put a booster down next to the tower and in range of the gripping mechanism, I would assume that they could also land it within hollowed out cylinder in the ground. by landing within a "sleeve" there would be no risk of the booster tipping over, the catch/grip could be accomplished many different ways given 360 degrees access around the booster and touchdown might even be softer with some creative venting and management of engine and air pressure (by the silo, not the booster).

China is already thinking about how to shoot down Starlink satellites because they think it poses a threat to their space ambitions.

The biggest worry to me in the current layout/design is that it has verry little margin for catastrophic error. If there is any problem with the landing and the ship crashes into the tower or anywhere near it, then it can burn down the whole site. There are fuel tanks, other boosters and all the vulnerable infrastructure exposed.

When talking about previous rocket engineers and the fact that re-usability had occurred to them but they would have come to the conclusion that it was impossible or the probability of success was so low... This implication seems to be that those previous generations' conclusions was wrong and SpaceX is proving that.

However, the reality is that a host of technologies that SpaceX is actively using had not been available or developed to the point where it could even be realistically be thought about. Materials advances, processing advancements, computer-aided design, higher levels of computerized data acquisition and systems control... We've been getting closer to re-usable rocket time and Musk is definitely the first to have realized it was the time to start trying and he assembled a team and pushed them to build on top of those advancements and greatly increate the scope of what is possible.

But it would likely have been inevitable.

What do these guys need to know? Hold on.
I think there is more to those two words than we know. Do you know what a no bounce hammer is and how it works? The cable system should absorb the shock, take up the slack. But the thought for the day, for the hour, for the moment is repeatability. Lets go back a couple of steps when we started work. Do you remember me suggesting horse shoes? The game? Guess not. It has a root in the flip and burn. Be that as it may. Here is a story for this time. When you first build a horse shoe pit (there are always two btw) the shoes bounce all over the place. As, over the years, we play the area around the pit becomes contoured. Each season we add a bag of sand or improve the surrounding area by planting grass, removing stones (buy a new beer cooler, ice chest).
The game changes, we are not so frustrated with horseshoes rolling away or skipping off our landing zone, end over end out of control. The toss, our game improves as we shape the horse shoe pit, one toss at a time. It develops into, idk kind of like a slide. We can pitch the shoe right in there and it sticks. Hard to explain, I hope you get my drift.

Now the analogy is not ended. The game of horse shoes is not just about numbers or aerodynamics. The real joy (not just drinking beers) is the partnership. Four players in all but two on each side from opposite teams. I get to talk and discuss (strategy, technique, skill, luck, tease, enjoy the company) of my adversary - for this game. We do not throw the horse shoes at each other. You can actually play with just two but that is more walking. With four it saves a few steps. Anyhoo, get to the point. No no no. The point is the journey, the point is the story, the point is the dance. We spend time together. As we play - over the years, through the seasons, the pit changes but with a little TLC in the spring, with a bag of seed and sand, our playing field improves, our game gets better and continues. We learn and develop friendship and respect for other players and make new ones.

If you bang up the landing tower or platform - leave it. Baseball gloves, shoes, many things benefit form being broken in. We are not done. We the startiles are incomplete - I keep thinking Nickelodeon green slime, but that is a story for another time.

I don't think the reason why we didn't build a re-usable rocket isn't because rocket scientists thought the probability was too low. It was because... COMPUTERS! If they had the same computers we had in the 60's, I'm sure the people of that time would've came up with a fully reusable rocket, similar to what Space X is doing.

Why it hasn't happened since 2000s when we had powerful enough computers and materials is because space became passé. We've gone to the moon, cold war was over, so government wasn't hungry as it was to innovate. It wasn't until they brought in the private industry that they made it possible. I don't think it's Musk's own unique genius that brought about re-usable rockets. He's definitely moving the ball forward, but it was circumstances that made it possible. Not because "Elon".

impressive, not the height so much as the windy breeze at the top level, while there is no wind at the ground! I want to bring Elon's attention to this. The ESA has 4 high lightning-protection towers around its launch sites. Maybe in Texas, it is not lightning, but the wind, that needs to be measured at different heights up to 400 meters at the launch/ and capture site around the tower. it needs to be measured in real-time and fed into the guidance of the returning HeavyBooster. When the winds would be too gusty, not steady, You'd better postpone a launch.
Another problem could be the insulation of electric cables in the tower if hot rocket-exhaust gases were drifting into the (upper part) of the structure.

The thing is, there is no other place on Earth where the development of space travel is pushed as hard as this. The important thing is to get mass into orbit as cheaply and safely as possible. Going to Mars and the Moon is just a bonus. Mass to orbit is what counts. It's the biggest hurdle to conquer, and is done rationally and boldly by SpaceX. For travel between planets and intercepting comets we need a different kind of ship though. Something like nuclear driven propulsion.

Building the tower to lean away from the chopsticks would allow the tower to bear more weight, be lighter, allow for (optional) guy-lines with reduced footprint, and shift load from the cabling system to the structure of the tower (basic geometry). This would also allow the chopsticks to be made longer and still be as strong, requiring less precise placement of the rocket during the landing sequence.

It is disingenuous to try to use saving the species as a reason for humans living off planet earth. All the expected events of destroying life on earth occur so far in the future that starting an off planet colony in 10,000 years instead of now would make no difference in human survivability. As for a rogue comet coming out of nowhere to destroy earth, the odds of that are so low as to be virtually assured not to happen within any reasonable time span.

The fundamental problem here is that if your goal was to protect humanity, there are FAR more cost effective ways to do it. Just building self sustaining underground cities right here on earth would save far more people and have a far greater chance of success. And you'd need that exact same technology and more to do the same thing on Mars anyway.

And finally, the trickle down effect/expand the economy argument is also bogus. Yes, there will be ancillary benefits to establishing a Mars colony, but those benefits would be just that... ancillary. Once again you'd get far more bang for your buck by directly investing in things we know are needed on earth. There will never be, or at least so far in the future as to be never be, any substantial trade between earth and Mars. The transportation costs and time are simply way to high to make it economically viable.

With all that said, Starship itself would greatly benefit humanity. Just don't try to pretend a Mars colony would ever be anything more than a vanity or scientific project. It's not going to make any noticeable impact down here on earth for humanity as a whole.

I have a question about the recent problem with the downpipe for methane that runs through the oxygen tank.
I ask because the pictures of the crumpled tube gave no indication of an inner tube within.
So, is it a double tube? That is, is there an annular space between the actual methane pipe and an outer pipe that touches the oxygen. I ask because if it is NOT a double tube, any leak will cause fuel and oxygen to mix which is likely not a survivable fault. Whereas, if it's a double tube, any leak is merely from a tank to the outside, which could be survivable.

I've had a thought. I don't know if it is viable, or if they've already thought of this or not, I'm not an engineer. What if the tower that catches the rocket had a pulley system? The arms that catch the rocket are on vertical rails, and those are connected to (dozens? hundreds?) of cables. The other ends of the cables are attached radially on the ground outside of the tower to motors that use breaks to slow down the cables. 1. this should use less fuel in the rockets, since they don't need to slow down as much. 2. the rocket won't 'smack' into the arms when it does 'land', and be less jarring for the rocket. 3. you can raise/lower the rocket with the cable system. 4. this system can be up-scaled easily for larger/future rockets?

Preserving life on earth against comet/asteroid strikes would be better achieved by investing resources in the construction of deep underground living spaces. You don't have to go very deep to be fully protected from all but Thea sized events. Any impact winter would only last a short time, and surface resources needed by those in shelters would be mere minutes away if needed, not millions of miles of space..
Deep underground spaces could be powered by geothermal systems and we (the Dutch esp) already have deep knowledge of hydroponic farming systems. We could build these shelters steadily over time, stocking them with resources and with seed banks and genetic storage. In fact, Elon is already involved with tunneling tech with the Boring Co. It wouldn't be a stretch to expand that technology into underground shelters, and it will probably be necessary for Mars anyway.
Frankly it's idiotic not to invest in such systems. We already create and use such spaces for storage of all manner of trivial items. If we could focus on making these shelter much more affordable we could protect far more people for far longer than any off-world colony. It should be made cheap enough to provide such shelters for every sizeable community (in addition to some hub mega-shelters)

I wonder how much more successful this tower and chop sticks will be (percentagewise) in ensuring a successful mission termination compared to just landing on a ground pad? It seems like the booster catch and second leading up to it will have to be going almost perfectly for success. With that kind of required perfection, why couldn't the booster just land on the ground? They can't reduce the speed enough?  What if a landing pad was mounted on at series of heavy duty spring loaded rings. The first ring at the top (just under the landing pad with low compressive resistance, and the rings below that gaining in compressive resistance strength all the way down. Perhaps that landing base then would only have to be about 25 feet of the ground at it's highest and when fully compressed by a booster might be about 5 feet off the ground. This way, a mission failure at the landing base could produce less damage to the spaceport than the tower and chopsticks method.
